_header: When charity is chosen with states to stand
Note: See 738 for a Yorkist interpretation of the same events
_description: On the visit to St. Paul’s by King Henry VI and his Queen (1458) with the Reconciliation of the Yorkist Lords — eight 8-line stanzas (ababbcbc)

BLCottNeroAVI.First Lines:
Whan charyte ys chosyn with statis to stondeStedfast and styll with
                    oute distaunce…
BLCottNeroAVI.Last Lines:
…And þat ys amys brynge to AmendyngThat England may
                    reioice the pees & vnite
BLCottNeroAVI.Note: Folio number reflects the most recent foliation.
BLCottNeroAVI.Editions:
Nicolas,  Nicholas Harris,  and  Edward Tyrrell, eds.  
             A Chronicle of London, from 1079 to 1483.
         London: Longman, 1827: 251.

BLCottVesBXVI.First Lines:
Whan charite is chosen with states to stondeStedfad and skill
                    without distaunceThan wrathe may be exiled out of this londeAnd god
                    oure gide to haue the gouernaunce…
BLCottVesBXVI.Last Lines:
…And þat is amys god bryng to AmendyngThat Anglond may
                    reioise to concorde & vnite
BLCottVesBXVI.Note:
16 cross-rhymed quatrains, abab, with a fifth line in the 14th
                    stanza.
BLCottVesBXVI.Editions:
